note.p: Birth: Wrington, Somerset, England, United Kingdom (29 August 1632)
Death: Oates, Essex, England, United Kingdom (28 October 1704)
Burial: The churchyard at High Laver, Essex, England, United Kingdom
Profession: Physician, colonial administrator
Research Field: Philosophy; natural philosophy; medicine

Education: Westminster School (1646-1652) where fellow pupils included John Dryden, Robert Hooke FRS, and Christopher Wren FRS; Christ Church, Oxford; BA (1656), MA (1658), MB (1675); incorporated at Cambridge (1663); Gray's Inn (admitted 1656)

Career: Christ Church, University of Oxford, Greek Lecturer (1660-1661), Tutor (1661-1666); Lecturer on Rhetoric (1662-1663), Censor of Moral Philosophy (1663-1664), all whilst remaining officially a student without taking religious orders as was usual, and instead carrying out chemical experiments and reading on medicine, after a period as an absentee student he later transfered to medical studentship (1675); secretary to Sir Walter Vane during his embassy to the elector of Brandenburg (1665); physician to Anthony Ashley Cooper, afterwards Earl of Shaftesbury and tutor to the Earl's son and later grandson (1667-1683); pupil of the physician Thomas Sydenham a prioneer in the study of infectious diseases (c.1667-1670); Secretary to the Proprietors of Carolina (1669-1675) in which capacity he helped to draft the constitution of the Carolinas including endorsement of slavery; shareholder in the Royal African Company and Bhama Adventurers Company, the latter founded by his patron Shaftesbury; registrar to the commissioners of the excise (1670-1675); Secretary of presentations (1672) during Shaftesbury's brief tenure as Lord Chancellor; Secretary and Treasurer to the Council of Trade (1673-1675) of which Shaftesbury was President; lived in France (1675-1679), chiefly at Montpellier and laterly inParis wherer he was tutor to the son of Sir John Bank FRS (1677-1679); suspected of complicity in the Shaftesbury Plots (1684); lived in Holland (1685-1689); Commissioner of Appeals (1689-1704); Commissioner of Trade and Plantations (1689-1704); published influential writings on civil government and political liberalism and philosophical theories of the human consciousness and sense of self
Membership: Fellow
Election Date: 26/11/1668
Proposers: Sir Paul Neile
